Graphical abstract To develop applicable catalysts for NOx-SCR by C3H6, SnO2/Beta catalysts with different loadings have been fabricated. The monolayer dispersion behavior of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite support have been explored thoroughly by using different characterization techniques. SnO2 can spontaneously dispersed on H-Beta zeolite support with a capacity of 0.291 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2, equaling to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading. Below the capacity, SnO2 is present in a sub-monolayer state, and has a close interaction with the support by donating electrons from Sn4+ in SnO2 to Si4+ in H-Beta zeolite. The sub-monolayer/monolayer dispersed SnO2 facilitates the formation of more surface vacancies, active superoxide anions and acid sites, which are important for the reactivity. As a consequence, 15% SnO2/Beta with nearly the threshold amount of SnO2 owns the biggest quantities of the two kinds of surface reactive sites, thus demonstrating the best reaction performance in the samples. It is discovered that selective NOx reduction by C3H6 over SnO2/Beta mainly follows a Langmuir-Hinselwood mechanism, in which surface formate/acetate and monodentate nitrate are the major reactive intermediates. Keywords SnO2/Beta catalyst NOx-SCR by C3H6 Monolayer dispersion threshold effect on the reactivity Surface O2- and acid sites Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism 1 Introduction In early 1980s, Xie et al. [1–4] discovered that metal oxides or salts can disperse spontaneously onto different supports, such as γ-Al2O3 [5], TiO2 [6] and CeO2 [7], to form monolayers, which was named by them as monolayer dispersion behavior. A catalyst with the monolayer dispersion capacity amount of supported active component often demonstrates a threshold effect on the reactivity, such as optimal activity or selectivity. The monolayer dispersion capacity is able to be measured by XRD, XPS and Raman extrapolation methods [8,9]. Xie et al. have investigated quite some dispersion systems, such as MoO3 or NiO on γ-Al2O3, MoO3 on SiO2 and CuCl on NaY. On the basis of the results, a Closed Packed Model has been established by them to explain the monolayer dispersion behavior [1]. It is worth noting here that the monolayer dispersion phenomenon has also been confirmed by some other scientists. For instance, Chen et al. have investigated the dispersion behavior of CuO on different supports to prepare catalysts for some environment protection reactions [10–12], and found the same phenomenon. They proposed an Incorporation Model to elucidate the reasons lying behind. Over the past 35 years, Wachs et al. have also investigated systematically the dispersion behavior of V2O5 and MoO3 on various supports to fabricate catalysts for organic compound conversion reactions [13,14]. The presence of monolayer dispersion phenomenon and the threshold effect was observed by them as well. In addition, it was reported by them that in a sub-monolayer/monolayer dispersion state, MOS bonds in the interfaces of the supported metal oxides (M) and the supports (S) are usually existing [15,16]. To explain the influence of the supports on the reactivity of the supported components, a Surface-Oxide Support Interaction (SOSI) theory has been suggested by them [17]. To date, the monolayer dispersion theory has been widely recognized, and become a vital guidance for catalyst design. Over the past decades, supporting active components on single component metal oxide supports, such as Al2O3 [18], SiO2 [19], ZrO2 [20], TiO2 [21], have been extensively investigated, and a relatively complete database has been built up. However, it is noticed that using composite oxides, such as Si-Al zeolites, ABO3 perovskite, AB2O4 Spinel, A2B2O7 pyrochlore etc., as supports has been rarely investigated [22–24]. On the basis of the above discussion, by using a composite oxide to support an active component, more abundant interface interactions could take place, thus giving more space to tune the reactivity, and getting better catalysts. Our recent work have proved that by supporting CuO onto a La2Sn2O7 pyrochlore support, a stable and active soot combustion catalysts can be obtained at the monolayer dispersion capacity [23]. By supporting NiO onto an Y2Ti2O7 pyrochlore support for methane dry reforming, a threshold effect on coking resistance of the prepared NiO/Y2Ti2O7 catalyst is evidently observed [24]. NOx released from mobile and stationary sources have become a global problem because of their harmful effect on the air atmosphere [25]. NOx-SCR is one of the most effective methods to reduce their pollutions. For automobile exhaust treatment, NOx-SCR by hydrocarbons over three-way catalysts (TWC), which generally contain precious metals, can remove unburned hydrocarbons and NOx at the same time, and is a mature, effective and economical technology [26,27]. Due to the limited sources and high price, people have tried to develop non-noble metal catalysts or catalysts with ultra-low precious metal content [28,29]. Since Iwamoto et al. [30] and Held et al. [31] found that Cu-ZSM-5 has considerable de-NOx performance and certain stability, catalysts based on various zeolites, such as ZSM-5 [32], SSZ [33], Beta [34], and SBA [35] have attracted tremendous attention. SnO2 is a metal oxide with an n-type semiconducting property, which contains abundant surface oxygen vacancies and acidic sites [36]. As early as 2000, Kung and co-workers have reported that SnO2/γ-Al2O3 catalysts possess good activity and stability towards NOx-SCR even in the existence of high O2 partial pressure and water vapor [37]. Recently, we also found that the reaction performance of SnO2/Al2O3 catalysts can be evidently improved by plasma treating [18]. Moreover, our group found that Sn-MFI catalysts prepared by incorporating Sn cations into the zeolite framework show good activity, stability and potent sulfur and water vapor resistance during NOx-SCR by NH3 [38]. Enlightened by these interesting studies, and with the target to design better catalysts for NOx-SCR, SnO2/Beta catalysts with different loadings were designed and fabricated in this work based on the monolayer dispersion theory. The interfacial interaction between SnO2 and H-Beta zeolite supports have been explored in detail by using multiple characterization techniques, and the reaction performance were explained and correlated with the characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation To get rid of the influence of Cl−1, a set of SnO2/Beta samples with different loadings were fabricated by a deposition-precipitation method. Specifically, before being used as a support, a commercial H-Beta zeolite (431 m2 g−1, Si/Al = 70, Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd) was calcined at 550 ℃ for 4 h in air. Afterwards, SnCl4·5H2O was dissolved into DDI water in a ratio of 1 g SnCl4·5H2O/1 mL DDI water to obtain a clear solution, and then an appropriate quantity of H-Beta was added into it. With continuous stirring, ammonia aqueous solution (15 mol L−1) was dropped slowly into the mixture until Sn4+ was completely precipitated, and the pH value was about 11.0. Then, the precipitate was repeatedly rinsed with DDI water until the TDS of the filtrate was lower than 20 ppm. The obtained solid product was dried at 110 °C overnight, and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in air atmosphere with a heating ramp of 2 °C min−1, which was followed by cooling to ambient temperature to get the ultimate SnO2/Beta catalysts. According to the SnO2 loadings, the catalysts are named 5% SnO2/Beta, 10% SnO2/Beta, 15% SnO2/Beta, 20% SnO2/Beta, 25% SnO2/Beta and 30% SnO2/Beta 2.2 Catalyst characterization and activity evaluation The information about the used equipment, operating conditions, experimental processes and parameters related to the experiments in this work are present in detail in the supporting information file. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD and XPS measurements To investigate the bulk structure of the as-prepared catalysts, the samples were evaluated by XRD. All the samples are crystallized well in the natural state, and show the diffraction characteristics of H-Beta zeolite, which was evidenced by a typical peak at 2θ = 22.8°. As can be seen from Fig. 1 (A), SnO2 shows three diffraction peaks at 2θ = 26.59° (110), 33.86° (101), and 51.79° (211). Interestingly, when SnO2 loading is less than 15%, no any diffraction peak of SnO2 can be detected, proving that SnO2 is highly distributed on H-Beta zeolite surface and in amorphous state. Nevertheless, when the SnO2 loading is higher than 15%, the characteristic diffraction peak of SnO2 starts to appear. It is mentioned here that the crystalline structure of H-Beta remains intact after loading SnO2. By increasing the SnO2 content, the diffraction peak of SnO2 becomes stronger, and the peak of H-Beta zeolite becomes weaker. Obviously, SnO2 displays monolayer dispersion behavior over H-Beta zeolite support, which should have a certain capacity [18]. Therefore, the monolayer dispersion threshold of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite was quantified by an XRD extrapolation method [8,39]. Specifically, the intensity of SnO2 (211) peak was measured for the samples, and normalized by that of the H-Beta zeolite (2θ = 22.8°) peak to get the ISnO2/IH-Beta ratios, which were then plotted versus the SnO2 loadings. As manifested in Fig. 1(B), a well-correlated line crosses the X-axis at 0.291 mmol 100 m−2, which is defined as the monolayer dispersion capacity of SnO2 on the support. It should be mentioned here that the accurate compositions of all catalysts used for the quantification have been confirmed by ICP (Table 1 ). The surface areas of all the catalysts, together with the pure H-Beta support, are included in Table 1 as well. Based on the support surface area, the extrapolated monolayer dispersion capacity is equal to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading, which is slightly higher than the SnO2 content of 15% SnO2/Beta sample. XPS technology was used to examine the surface structures of the samples. As shown in Fig. 2 (A), two Sn 3d peaks around 495.3 and 487.0 eV [40], corresponding to Sn 3d3/2 and Sn 3d5/2 of Sn4+ are observed. In Fig. 2(B) and (C), pure H-Beta zeolite support reveals Si 2p and Al 2p bands at 103.6 and 75.0 eV, respectively. In all the SnO2/Beta samples, the characteristic peaks of both SnO2 and H-Beta zeolite can be observed, but there are some subtle changes. With the increasing of SnO2 loading, the Sn 3d peaks become stronger, while the Si 2p and Al 2p peaks become weaker. Furthermore, compared with individual SnO2 and H-Beta zeolite, the binding energy of Sn 3d peak in SnO2/Beta catalysts shifts to a higher range, while that of Si 2p shifts to a lower range. Since the binding energy of Al 2p peak in all the catalysts does not change with SnO2 loading, it is apparent that Sn4+ in the supported SnO2 donates partially its electrons solely to Si4+ in H-Beta zeolite support, hence generating a strong interaction. To be precise, the monolayer dispersion threshold of SnO2 over H-Beta support was validated by using an XPS extrapolation method as well [41,42]. In detail, for each sample, the intensity of the Sn 3d5/2 peak (486.7 eV) was divided by that of the Si 2p peak to achieve a set of ISn3d/ISi2p ratios, which are plotted versus the SnO2 loadings. As demonstrated in Fig. 2(D), two well correlated line having varied slopes are crossed at a turning point at 0.288 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2 H-Beta zeolite surface, which is regarded as the monolayer dispersion threshold of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite. Within the experimental error, the value is well consistent with the monolayer dispersion threshold quantified by the XRD extrapolation method. In summary, with H-Beta zeolite as the support, SnO2 can disperse spontaneously on its surface. Based on both of the XRD and XPS results, the monolayer dispersion threshold of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite is around 0.291 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2 H-Beta zeolite surface, which is equal to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading. At the dispersion capacity, SnO2 is in a monolayer state. Below the capacity, SnO2 should be in a sub-monolayer state. Above the capacity, excess SnO2 will then accumulate on the initially formed SnO2 monolayer gradually to form crystallites. The average SnO2 crystallite size improves with the increasing of its loading (Table 1). When SnO2 is in a sub-monolayer/monolayer state, it might have a stronger interaction with the H-Beta zeolite support surface, hence they could display some special reaction performance [18,43]. 3.2 Activity evaluation The reactivity of NOx reduction by C3H6 over SnO2/Beta catalysts with different loadings was evaluated. For comparison, the performance of H-Beta zeolite was also studied under the same condition. As manifested in Fig. 3 (A), H-Beta zeolite shows certain reactivity and selectivity for the reaction, due to the existing of surface Bronsted acid sites, which is important for the adsorption and activation of C3H6 and NOx molecules [44]. The NOx conversion over it increases with the reaction temperature, and 33.5% conversion can be obtained at 550 °C. With the addition of SnO2, the NOx reduction performance of all the SnO2/Beta catalysts is obviously improved, especially above 450 °C. In comparison with pure H-Beta, the reaction behaviors of the SnO2/Beta catalysts are differed, with the appearance of a zenith NOx conversion at 500 °C regardless of the SnO2 loading. This seems to indicate that after supporting SnO2, new surface reactive sites have been generated, which are favorable for the reaction. More importantly, it is discovered that the reaction performance of the catalysts is closely dependent on the SnO2 loading. Below 15%, the reactivity of the catalysts improves evidently with the increasing of SnO2 loading. The highest reactivity is availed on 15% SnO2/Beta among all the samples, which can get a maximum NOx conversion around 85%. Whereas, further increasing SnO2 loading begins to decrease the reactivity, and which keeps on degrading with the increasing of SnO2 loading. For more complete information, the reaction rates normalized by catalyst weight (Rw) and catalyst surface area (Rs) are thus calculated at different temperatures. As shown in Figs. 2(B) and S1 (A) and (B) for 500, 475 and 525 °C, respectively, they are well consistent with the NOx conversion trend, and 15% SnO2/Beta catalyst shows the best activity. As discussed above, 16% loading is the monolayer dispersion threshold of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite support. On the basis of these facts, it is reasonable to presume that the SnO2 species present in highly dispersed states as sub-monolayer or monolayer is beneficial to the reaction. On the contrary, the formation of SnO2 crystallites can impact inversely on the reactivity of the catalysts. Figs. 3(C) and S1(C) show the N2 and N2O selectivity over the catalysts. Regardless of the SnO2 loading, N2 is the main product on all the catalysts. Moreover, 15% SnO2/Beta catalyst, which has almost monolayer dispersion capacity amount of SnO2, exhibits the highest N2 selectivity as well. This has testified strongly that the monolayer dispersed SnO2 species is not only favorable for the activity, but also beneficial to the N2 selectivity. When the SnO2 loading exceeds the dispersion threshold, the accumulation of excessive SnO2 micro-crystallites might destroy some surface active sites at the interface, hence resulting in a decrease in the reaction performance [17,45]. Sulfur and water vapor in exhaust gases are two key factors leading to catalyst deactivation. Therefore, in existing of water vapor and SO2, the reaction stability of 15% SnO2/Beta was evaluated at 500 °C. As shown in Fig. 3(D), the introduction of 100 ppm SO2 or 5% water vapor can degrade NOx conversion evidently. But it can be fully restored after stopping the poisoning components. It is noted that 5% water vapor decreases the NOx conversion more severely than 100 ppm SO2. In contrast, if 100 ppm SO2 and 5% water vapor are fed together, more severe NOx conversion drop happens, but which can still be regenerated. These facts have proved that SO2 or water vapor competes only with the reactants for the surface active sites, but has no structure damage to the SnO2/Beta catalysts. In brief, a distinct threshold effect is observed for selective NOx reduction by C3H6 over SnO2/Beta catalysts. It is proposed that a catalyst with the optimal NOx-SCR performance can be designed by covering the H-Beta zeolite support surface with the monolayer capacity amount of SnO2. Importantly, SnO2/Beta catalysts demonstrate strong resistance to SO2 or water vapor deactivation as well. With further investigation and optimization, SnO2/Beta catalysts having real application possibility could be fabricated. 3.3 N2 sorption results N2 sorption was employed to analyze the SnO2/Beta samples. As manifested in Fig. S2(A), all the SnO2/Beta catalysts, together with the pure H-Beta support, have a type I isotherm, indicating a typical micro-porous zeolite structure. Notably, in the p/p0 range of 0.5–1.0, an H3-type hysteresis loop is observed, which can be ascribed to some small meso-pores in the zeolite structure. The presence of both micro-pores around 0.6 nm and meso-pores around 5.0 nm in the structure can also be seen in Fig. S2(B), the pore diameter distribution profiles of the catalysts. For clarity, the detailed mean pore sizes and pore volumes of the micro-pores and meso-pores are included in Table 1. In contrast to pure H-Beta support, the addition of SnO2 drops the surface areas of the SnO2/Beta samples obviously. The higher the SnO2 loading, the lower the surface area. This proves that the blockage of the pores of H-Beta zeolite support by SnO2 occurs. Interestingly, by increasing the SnO2 loading, the average pore sizes and pore volumes of the meso-pores display no evident change; but the pore sizes and pore volumes of the micro-pores decrease gradually. This indicates strongly the blockage of the micro-pores of H-Beta zeolite support by SnO2 species. It is worth noting here that the surface area of 15% SnO2/Beta, the catalyst with the optimal reactivity, is not the largest. This indeed implies that surface area change is not a critical element influencing the reaction performance. 3.4 H2-TPR study H2-TPR was employed to probe the redox characteristics, with the reduction curves of the catalysts depicted in Fig. 4 (A). SnO2 exhibits a main peak at 689 °C, which is ascribed to the reducing of Sn4+ in SnO2 to metallic Sn [18]. Due to the potent SiO and AlO bonds, H-Beta zeolite shows no any reduction. However, all the SnO2/Beta catalysts show mainly two groups of reduction peaks. The group of multiple small peaks below 400 °C are assignable to the reducing of loosely bound surface oxygen species. The high temperature major peak around 600 °C can be attributed to the reducing of Sn4+ to Sn [46]. The quantitative results in Table 2 based on the high temperature peak indicate that all the catalysts have an O/Sn mole ratio of 2/1, that is the stoichiometric ratio of SnO2 reduction. This validates further that irrespective of the loading, SnO2 is the predominant surface component. Interestingly, the reduction temperature shift of the catalysts demonstrates also apparent threshold effect. For the three catalysts having SnO2 loadings below the monolayer dispersion threshold, the temperature decreases from 616 to 591 °C by improving the SnO2 loading from 5% to 15%, because the concentration of the dispersed surface SnO2 increases, and the nucleation of metallic Sn becomes easier during the reducing process [47]. However, above the monolayer dispersion capacity, the reduction temperature of this major peak keeps on shifting to higher temperature from 20% to 35% loading, and becomes closer to the reduction temperature of bulk SnO2. This in fact provides extra evidence to testify the formation of SnO2 crystallites above monolayer dispersion capacity, whose mean size improves gradually with the SnO2 loading increase (Table 1), thus increasing the reduction temperature slowly. Apparently, with a loading around monolayer dispersion threshold, the supported SnO2 species becomes the easiest to be reduced, which might be one of the reasons accounting for the best reaction performance of 15% SnO2/Beta. 3.5 O2-TPD study To surface oxygen characteristics was further probed by O2-TPD, with the results depicted in Fig. S3. All the SnO2/Beta samples, including the H-Beta support, display two desorption peaks, implying the presence of oxygen sites with differed properties [48]. The peak below 400 °C (labelled as α) is considered as the desorbing of loosely bound surface oxygen, while the peak higher than 400 °C (labelled as β) could be due to the desorbing of facile surface lattice oxygen. The H-Beta support used in this study possesses a high surface area, and both micro-pores and meso-pores. Therefore, it is easy to understand that it could have surface defects, which is facile to adsorb gas phase O2 to form some reactive oxygen species [49]. Furthermore, part of its surface lattice oxygen could be unstable, thus being desorbed at elevated temperature and giving a peak at 525 °C. The co-existing of both Bronsted acid sites and active oxygen species indeed explains that H-Beta itself shows certain reactivity to NOx reduction by C3H6. After loading SnO2, both the α and β peaks of SnO2/Beta catalysts move to a little higher temperatures, indicating the property change of the surface oxygen sites. The quantitative oxygen desorption results are shown in Table 3 . Interestingly, below the monolayer dispersion threshold of 16%, the active oxygen quantities of both α and β peaks go up by increasing the SnO2 loading, and reach the maximum with 15% SnO2/Beta, which has a SnO2 loading close to the monolayer dispersion threshold. Above the monolayer threshold, the amount of active oxygen species starts to go down proportionally. This strongly testifies that the sub-monolayer/monolayer SnO2 species highly dispersed on H-Beta support surface is in favor of creating active surface oxygen species. On the contrary, the formed SnO2 crystallites are harmful to the creating of active surface oxygen species. During a typical NOx selective reduction process, NO reacts to active oxygen species first to form NO2, and then adsorbed on the catalysts surface to form reactive adsorbates [18]. In turn, the adsorbates will react with the reductants, such as C3H6 in this study, to form the final products. Hence, the reactive surface oxygen sites are of great importance for NOx-SCR reaction [38]. 3.6 EPR and XPS studies The surface oxygen species was further investigated with EPR and XPS methods. Fig. 5 (A) displays the EPR results of H-Beta zeolite support and the optimal 15% SnO2/Beta catalyst. Five different peaks were observed around g = 1.940, 2.060, 2.126, 2.228 and 2.534. According to literature, the peaks at g = 2.534, 2.228 and 1.940 can be attributed to the hyperfine structure of 27Al (I = 5/2) frame [50,51]. The signal at g = 2.126 is due to the oxygen vacancies formed on the catalyst surface [52]. It can be seen that the oxygen vacancy signal is greatly enhanced after adding SnO2, substantiating that the highly dispersed sub-monolayer/monolayer SnO2 species is in favor of generating surface oxygen defects, which are able to induce the formation of surface reactive oxygen sites [53]. Moreover, the signal at g = 2.062 is attributable to the surface O2 − anions [54,55], which implies that this O2 − could be the main surface reactive oxygen sites on SnO2/Beta devoting to NOx-SCR reaction. The XPS, O 1s spectra have been specially analyzed for the catalysts in Fig. 5(B). On the basis of EPR measurements and literatures, [40,56,57] the asymmetric O 1s bands of all the sample are able to be divided into three symmetrical bands at 533.1, 532.2 and 530.9 eV, corresponding to surface superoxide (O2 −), OSi−OH of H-Beta zeolite and lattice O2-. The integrated areas of the three peaks are thus quantified for each sample in Table 4 . Similar to O2-TPD experiments, the relative quantity of surface O2 − sites improves proportionally to the increasing of SnO2 loading, and reach the maximum over 15% SnO2/Beta, the catalyst has a SnO2 loading close to the monolayer capacity. In contrast, all the SnO2/Beta samples possessing SnO2 loadings above the monolayer capacity have smaller quantities of surface O2 − sites, and exhibit lower reaction performance. This is well consistent with the O2-TPD results, confirming that the surface oxygen sites amount is of vital importance for NOx-SCR by C3H6. 3.7 NH3-TPD study In the structure of C3H6 molecules, a Π bond with rich electrons is present, which can be adsorbed and activated on surface acid sites to form reactive intermediates [58]. In turn, they will react with NOx adsorbates to generate the final products. Hence, the surface acidity is very important for NOx-SCR by C3H6 as well. The acidity of the catalysts was thus estimated by NH3-TPD, with the patterns manefested in Fig. S4(A). Pure SnO2 possesses certain surface Lewis acidity, [36] which shows a small NH3 desorption peak around 95 °C. As mentioned above, H-Beta support possesses surface Bronsted acid sites, thus it also displays an NH3 desorption peak around 108 °C. For all the SnO2/Beta catalysts, a broad and larger NH3 desorption peak is observed around 110 °C, which could mainly originate from surface Lewis acid sites over the dispersed SnO2 species [38]. The quantitative results in Table 5 show that the NH3 desorption amount of the samples follows the sequence of 15% SnO2/Beta >10% SnO2/Beta >20% SnO2/Beta >25% SnO2/Beta >30% SnO2/Beta > 5% SnO2/Beta >H-Beta > SnO2. It is apparent that 15% SnO2/Beta, the sample with nearly the monolayer dispersion capacity amount of SnO2 loading, owns the largest amount of surface acid sites. Fig. 6 (A) plots the relation between the NOx conversion at 500 °C and the amount of surface acid sites on the catalysts. Obviously, the reactivity of the samples is almost proportional to the surface acid sites quantity, which testifies strongly that the surface acidity is one of the vital reasons to control the NOx-SCR performance over SnO2/Beta catalysts. 3.8 C3H6-TPD study To validate the importance of surface acid sites for propylene adsorption, C3H6-TPD experiments were conducted on the catalysts. As displayed in Fig. S4(B), although on the NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts, only one broad NH3 desorption peak is observed, two C3H6 desorption peaks located around 130 and 260 °C are detected evidently. This indicates that two kinds of surface acid sites with differed strength are present, which can adsorb/desorb C3H6 molecules at different temperatures. Fig. 6(B) plots the NOx conversion at 500 °C against the C3H6 desorption amount of the catalysts. It is observed that a catalyst with a larger quantity of desorbed C3H6 usually has a higher reactivity, which testifies that the adsorption and activation of C3H6 molecules should be a critical step for the reaction. Fig. 6(C) exhibits the relationship between surface acid sites and C3H6 desorption amount. It is found that the C3H6 adsorption/desorption quantity is nearly proportional to the surface acid site amount. 15% SnO2/Beta, the sample containing the largest quantity of surface acid sites, adsorbs the largest quantity of C3H6. 3.9 In situ DRIFTS studies DRIFTS studies To figure out the reaction intermediates and possible pathways, 15% SnO2/Beta, the best catalyst in this work, was selected for a series of in situ DRIFTS experiments. For the first series of experiments, C3H6 gas was introduced first onto the sample to produce adsorbed hydrocarbon intermediates, and their reactivity with NOx was then explored. For the second series of experiments, NOx gas was introduced first onto the sample to produce adsorbed nitrate intermediates, and their reaction with C3H6 was then investigated. 3.9.1 Reaction between NO + O2 and adsorbed hydrocarbon intermediates First, the catalyst was treated in a 30 mL min−1 Ar flow at 400 °C for 1 h to clean the surface. The 0 min curve in Fig. 7 (A) indicates that the catalyst surface is nearly clean, with only several weak infrared bands. After this, a mixed gas of 500 ppm C3H6 + 5% O2/Ar flows into the in situ cell without changing the temperature. After 1 min, the generation of quite several new infrared bands is observed, proving that the chemical adsorption of C3H6 molecules took place. According to the previous literatures [59,60], the adsorption peaks in the range of 2800−3000 cm−1 are due to the asymmetric and symmetric vibration of the CH bonds in the CH3/CH2 groups of the adsorbed C3H6; and the bands at 2141, 2085 and 1930 cm−1 are due to adsorbed CO. In addition, the peak appearing near 2364 cm−1 can be ascribed to adsorbed CO2 [27]. Besides, the peak at 1618 cm−1 belongs to adsorbed formate, the bands at 1545 and 1246 cm−1 belong to acetate species, and the peak at 1740 cm−1 can be attributed to CO vibration of surface carbonates [61–63]. After 40 min, when the catalyst surface has been saturated, the gas was changed to a 500 ppm NO + 5% O2/Ar flow. As seen in Fig. 7(B), the peak intensity of formate and acetate species at 1618 and 1246 cm−1 was gradually weakened, and a new peak appeared in 1786 cm−1, which can be attributed to adsorbed NO species [64]. This indicates that both formate and acetate could be the reactive hydrocarbon intermediates. Notably, the intensity of the 1545 cm−1 peak assigned to the adsorbed acetate decreased in the first 5 min, and then started to increase. The reason lies in the gradual formation of adsorbed monodentate nitrate species, which displays an over-lapped vibration at this wavenumber [62]. Meanwhile, the adsorbed CO peaks in the range of 1900−2100 cm−1 decreased gradually as well after the introduction of NO + O2. Interestingly, as displayed in the enlarged Fig. 7(C), a novel isocyanate (–NCO) peak at 2233 cm−1 was detected after 10 min (see the enlarged figure beside), whose intensity was gradually increased and stabilized at 30 min [62,63]. This implies that the formation of the final N2 and COx products might go through this isocyanate (–NCO) intermediate [18]. 3.9.2 Reaction between C3H6 and adsorbed nitrate intermediates Same to the above procedures, the catalyst was purified first, then a 500 ppm NO + 5% O2/Ar flow is switched into the in situ cell to produce adsorbed NOx species over the catalyst surface. Fig. 8 (A) indicates that some bands formed quickly after 5 min. The bands at 1548 and 1518 cm−1 can be ascribed to monodentate nitrate [65,66], and the peak at 1646 cm−1 can be assigned to bridged nitrate [64]. Additionaly, the peak at 1460 cm−1 can be assigned to bidentate nitrate [67]. In contrast, the peaks at 1787 and 1733 cm−1 can be assigned to gas phase NO and NO2 in sequence [63]. After switching the gas to a C3H6 + 5% O2/Ar feed, Fig. 8(B) manifests that the peaks corresponding to surface monodentate nitrate at 1548 and 1518 cm−1 gradually decrease. However, the bands respective to bridged nitrate and bidentate nitrate remain nearly un-changed. This proves that monodentate nitrate should be the predominant reactive intermediate in the reaction process. It is noted here that the intensity of the 1548 cm−1 peak of monodentate nitrate remained nearly constant. The reason lies in the gradual formation of adsorbed acetate species, which exhibits an over-lapped vibration at this wavenumber [62]. According to the in situ DRIFTS results, the reaction pathway is depicted in Scheme 1 here. Over SnO2/Beta catalysts, NO react to O2 first to generate NO2, which is then adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form monodentate, bridged and bidentate nitrate species. The monodentate nitrate is the major reactive NOx adsorbate, which can react effectively with the adsorbed C3H6 species, that is acetate and formate intermediates, to form the final products through –NCO species. Obviously, on SnO2/Beta catalysts, NOx-SCR by C3H6 is a double molecules reaction, which involves both of the NOx and C3H6 adsrobates. Therefore, it is concluded that the reaction mainly follows a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. 3.10 A brief discussion As discussed in the Introduction part, monolayer dispersion of metal oxides or salts on single component supports, such as Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2, has been widely investigated, and relatively complete database has been established over the past decades [1]. Several models have also been proposed by different researchers to explain monolayer dispersion phenomenon [5,68]. However, the monolayer dispersion behaviors of active components onto composite oxide supports, such as zeolites and other metal oxide compounds, have been rarely investigated, and many fundamental issues still remain unclear. To solve this problem, we have intentionally design several catalyst systems by using supports containing at least two kinds of metal cations to probe the interactions between the supported components and the supports [23,24]. Furthermore, the effects of the interactions on the performance of various reactions are elucidated. In this work, a series of SnO2/Beta were fabricated and tested for NOx-SCR by C3H6. It is observed that a monolayer dispersion behavior of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite also occurs, with a threshold of 0.291 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2 H-Beta zeolite surface, equaling to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading. Below the threshold, SnO2 is present in a sub-monolayer state, which has an intimate interaction with H-Beta through electron donation from Sn4+ in the supported SnO2 to Si4+ in H-Beta zeolite support, as evidenced by the XPS results. Above the threshold, SnO2 crystallites start to form on the initial SnO2 monolayer. The SnO2 existing state significantly influences the surface properties of SnO2/Beta catalysts, thus eventually affecting the NOx-SCR performance. As summarized in Fig.9 , when the SnO2 loading is below the monolayer dispersion threshold (16%), both the quantities of surface reactive oxygen species and acid sites improve proportionally with the increasing of SnO2 contents, and reach the maximum amount at the monolayer capacity. Further increasing the SnO2 content degrades the quantities of both. Simultaneously, the NOx-SCR reactivity of the catalysts displays an evident threshold effect, which changes parallelly to the change of the surface reactive oxygen species and acid sites. Therefore, the quantities of these two kind of sites are the key factors to control the reaction performance of NOx-SCR [69]. 15% SnO2/Beta, the catalyst with nearly the threshold amount of loaded SnO2, contains the largest quantities of the two types of surface active sites, thus demonstrating the best reaction performance amongst all the samples. 4 Conclusion In this work, to develop catalysts with application potential for NOx-SCR by C3H6, a series of SnO2/Beta catalysts with different loadings have been designed. By using multiple characterization means, the monolayer dispersion behavior of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite support have been explored and elucidated in depth. (1) It is discovered that SnO2 can spontaneously dispersed on H-Beta zeolite surface with a monolayer dispersion capacity of 0.291 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2, which is equal to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading. Below the capacity, SnO2 is present in a sub-monolayer state, which has an intimate interaction with the support through electron donation from Sn4+ in SnO2 to Si4+ in H-Beta zeolite. (2) The sub-monolayer/monolayer dispersed SnO2 can facilitate the generation of more surface vacancies, active superoxide species and acid sites, which are crucial to determine the reaction performance. As a consequence, 15% SnO2/Beta, the catalyst with nearly the threshold amount of SnO2, owns the largest amount of both kinds of surface active sites, thus demonstrating the optimal reaction performance in all the samples. (3) It is discovered that NOx-SCR by C3H6 over SnO2/Beta catalysts mainly follows a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, in which surface formate/acetate and monodentate nitrate are the major reactive intermediates. coredata.dc:description: To develop applicable catalysts for NOx-SCR by C3H6, SnO2/Beta catalysts with different loadings have been fabricated. The monolayer dispersion behavior of SnO2 on H-Beta zeolite support have been explored thoroughly by using different characterization techniques. SnO2 can spontaneously dispersed on H-Beta zeolite support with a capacity of 0.291 mmol SnO2 per 100 m2, equaling to 16 wt.% SnO2 loading. Below the capacity, SnO2 is present in a sub-monolayer state, and has a close interaction with the support by donating electrons from Sn4+ in SnO2 to Si4+ in H-Beta zeolite. The sub-monolayer/monolayer dispersed SnO2 facilitates the formation of more surface vacancies, active superoxide anions and acid sites, which are important for the reactivity. As a consequence, 15% SnO2/Beta with nearly the threshold amount of SnO2 owns the biggest quantities of the two kinds of surface reactive sites, thus demonstrating the best reaction performance in the samples. It is discovered that selective NOx reduction by C3H6 over SnO2/Beta mainly follows a Langmuir-Hinselwood mechanism, in which surface formate/acetate and monodentate nitrate are the major reactive intermediates.
coredata.dc:title: Expounding the monolayer dispersion threshold effect of SnO2/Beta catalysts on the selective catalytic reduction of NOx (NOx-SCR) by C3H6

dcterms:subject.$: Monolayer dispersion threshold effect on the reactivity
